Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The Buzz about Bee Behavior, Taking an Interdisciplinary Approach to Assess Cognitive Impairments behind Pollinator Declines
Award.AbstractNarration:
Animal pollinators are declining in abundance, diversity, and geographic range at an alarming rate worldwide. Given the critical role of pollinators in natural and agricultural ecosystems, these declines represent a significant threat to global biodiversity and crop production. However, conservation and restoration efforts to address this important problem are impeded by a lack of information on mechanistic links between environmental stressors and population decline. To address this important knowledge gap, the investigators will examine sub-lethal effects of chronic exposure to different stressors on brain functions important for pollinator survival and reproduction. The investigators will develop quantitative tools to measure physiological and molecular responses to environmental stressors in pollinators, and then correlate those changes with changes in their brain functioning and behavior. In addition to elucidating causal factors in pollinator decline, the research will allow for the development of ecological tools for monitoring pollinator health in wild populations, thereby accelerating efforts to identify and protect species particularly susceptible to decline. The investigators will also engage in pollinator-focused educational outreach activities for K-12 educators, students, particularly those from underrepresented groups, and the local community.

This project utilizes a highly interdisciplinary approach to characterize mechanisms linking exposure to pesticides and infectious agents to cognition-based behavioral impairments in bumblebee pollinators native to North America. Molecular and immunological approaches will be used to develop methods for the identification and quantification of compounds produced by the humoral pathway of the bee immune system in response to infection. Ecotoxicological approaches will be used to develop tools for the quantification of pesticide and metabolite residues in specific bee tissues after chronic exposure to neonicotinoid pesticides. Measures of pesticide and immune responses will be correlated with performance on standard behavioral assays of cognitive function in order to identify the mechanistic underpinnings of behavioral alterations observed when bees are exposed to environmental stressors. All digital data generated from the research will be stored on an EMC Isilon storage array that is maintained by the local institution's Center for Academic and Research Computing. All analyzed primary data under this award will be promptly published to peer-reviewed journal publications. The findings of the research will also be disseminated at domestic and international professional conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pollinators are declining in abundance, species richness, and geographic range at an alarming rate worldwide.   These declines have important consequences for global food production, biodiversity, and the agro-economy due to the critical role that pollinators play in reproductive output of wild and crop plants.  Yet, the cause of pollinator decline remains poorly understood.  To address this important knowledge gap, our research project combined approaches from behavioral ecology, psychology, ecotoxicology, molecular biology and immunology to examine the potential effects of two important environmental stressors – neonicotinoid pesticides (Objective 1) and novel infectious agents (Objective 2) – on the survival of one of the most important native pollinators in North America, the bumblebee (Bombus spp.).  The goal of our first objective was to test for differential effects of chronic ingestion of field-realistic doses of the neonicotinoid clothianidin on work, male and queen bumblebees.  Through a series of individually-based feeding trials, our research demonstrated for the first time that clothianidin is considerably more toxic to males than to worker or queen bees, even when controlling for size differences among individuals.  Specifically, we discovered that ingestion of 10 ppb (0.750 ng of clothianidin/day) had a chronic LC50 (50% mortality in the test population) of 5 days in workers and remarkably, 3 days in males.  Toxic effects of clothianidin also occurred at lower doses in males than workers, with ingestion of 7 ppb (0.525 ng of clothianidin/day) having no effect on worker mortality but producing a chronic LC50 of 6 days in males.  To put these findings in perspective, non-native honeybee workers, which are currently the ‘gold standard’ for pesticide risk assessment by the EPA, have a chronic LC50 of 20ppb for clothianidin.  Clearly, a ‘one-size-fits-all’ approach to role of pesticides in pollinator decline needs to be re-considered.  Our subsequent molecular experiments revealed that male and worker bumblebees also differ markedly in their genetic response to chronic oral clothianidin exposure, with males showing a greater number of differentially expressed genes than workers (186 genes versus 133 genes, respectively).  Importantly, workers showed a higher constitutive expression and males a higher induced expression of different detoxification-related genes, suggesting for the first time that pesticide detoxification mechanisms in bumblebees may be sex-specific. 

The goal of our second objective was to test for effects of immune-stimulation on the ability of the bumblebee brain to flexible utilize floral information, which is crucial for foragers to effectively harvest and compete for nectar rewards in highly diverse and rapidly changing floral environments.   Studies in humans and other vertebrates have established that such ‘immune-brain connectively’ is common and mediated through immune system products called cytokines.  Cytokines are functionally similar immune-products in bees in other insects called antimicrobial peptides (AMPs), which are produced subsequent to infection by bacterial and fungal agents.  To test for AMP-mediated effects on cognitive flexibility in bumblebees, we developed a novel experimental paradigm in which individual foragers first consecutively learned simple color and odor discrimination tasks and then had the opportunity to freely choose between tasks in a mixed task environment.  We tested the ability of foragers  to flexibly and rapidly switch between cognitive tasks in the assay in the following three treatment groups : 1) bees injected with LPS, which induces AMP production; 2) bees injected with elastomer, which stimulates a different type of immune response in bees than LPS; 3) bees injected with insect Ringer’s solution, which provides a vehicle and injection control.  We found that bees in the elastomer and Ringer groups readily switched between tasks and showed minimal reductions in task performance while doing so.  In contrast, bees the LPS-injected group rarely swiched between tasks (99% of choices were task repetitions)  and showed a significant reduction in task performance, indicating a substantial reduction in cognitive flexibility.   Subsequent analysis of AMP gene expression patterns showed that 2 out of 4 AMPs were highly expressed in the brains of bees for over 24hrs and continued to be highly expressed (one AMP showed an 80 fold increase) in whole bee preparations for up to 5 days.  Although these findings are consistent with the view that bumblebee brain function can impaired by the products of an immune response to an infectious agent rather than the agent itself, further genetic work is needed to confirm this assertion.  Nonetheless, our work clearly shows immune-brain connectivity is not limited to vertebrates.  Collectively, our research significantly advances our understanding of how and why environmental stressors can alter fitness-related behaviors to drive bumblebee population decline.  Our behavioral and genetic data have important implications for future environmental regulations related to pesticide use in agricultural and residential areas, and will also play a key role in the development of effective strategies to conserve and restore wild bumblebee populations in North America.
